Notes: Appears to be only one species in North America, terrestrial. Lay eggs in foliage, and are found on bark. But also sometimes eat algae.

common_name: Miner, Bare-miner, Fairy, and Oxaeine Be

Notes: Larvae found in or near decaying wood or vegetation, fermenting sap, animal manure, tree trunks, mud, and sometimes sewage.
Larvae usually in soil or decaying wood

common_name: Small mayflies or small minnow mayflies

Notes: Larvae mostly parasitoids, terrestrial
Found in soil and leaf litter
Parasitic
Egg deposition occurs in terrestrial environments in crevices or on foliage
Larvae are scavengers of carrion and dung
Habitat is galls
"They are not strictly aquatic or terrestrial."
"Larvae are mostly aquatic filter feeders."
Larvae in the bark of trees.
"Larvae in small bodies of water such as those isolated at the edges of bogs or small lakes."
"Larvae are stem borers, root feeders, leaf tiers/ miners, or on/in aquatic vegetation."

common_name: Snout and bark beetles, or weevils
Notes: "Most larvae and adults occur and feed on all parts of plants."
terrestrial, parasites on mammals and birds
Larvae are parasitic
"No truly aquatic species." Larvae live in moist environments such as soil, moist sand, or rotting organic matter.
Habitat: around decaying vegetables and fruit

Lots of papers published on this family where authors sample in soil, discussions of catching the family in pitfall traps, discussions of this family occurring in canopies. However, there are some mentions of aquatic forms of this family on the internet, though there does not seem to be any sort of consensus, even if you explore at the genus level. Classifying as unknown.
Larvae are aquatic to terrestrial; adult female attracted to decaying organic matter. Indicators useful in forensic ento.
Only genus in this dataset is Trybliographa, which parasitizes mostly Anthomyiidae, a terrestrial fly.
Larvae feed on decaying matter, fungi.
ectoparasitoids or predators
Not much known about family; source says larvae have been found in terrestrial habitats.
Most are aquatic except for those in the subfamily Sphaeridiinae.
Parasitoid wasp family, larvae in host insects
Little information; some suggestion it could occur in or next to lakes, otherwise seems to mostly be a soil dweller.
"Larvae inhabit damp, dark places, sometimes caves, most often under bracket fungi." Can also consume smaller invertebrates, spores; some cannibalize pupa of their own species.

common_name: Minute brown scavenger beetles, fungus beetles

Notes: Larvae feed on "decaying vegetation in moist areas."
"Larvae under leaves and decaying plant remains in gardens, forests, and meadows in both dry and moist locations."

"Semi-aquatic" -- found on surface of water, but can also occur in forest on leaf litter, damp moss, or seeping rocks. Classifying as aquatic because Bug Guide lists their diet as "small aquatic organisms found on the water surface." The one genus in these samples (Mesovelia) also has its habitat listed as "lentic."
Larvae in "decayed vegetation, old manure, or fungi."

Larvae in dung, carrion, soil, nests, decaying vegetation, according to Bug Guide. Wikipedia says they can be in fresh water too, but states "Larvae mainly develop in decaying plant material or maure." Mostly terrestrial habitats, so labelling as terrestrial.
Millipedes live in "moist habitats under rocks, rotting logs, organic debris, etc."
Predatory mites
Many habitats listed in UWM source, including aquatic, forest floors, edges of wetlands, roots of grasses/crops
Usually found in streams and rivers
Highly variable (both sources provide extensive lists that include both aquatic and terrestrial habitats).
In "Hydrachnidia" group; habitats include streams, marshes, treeholes, hot springs, deep lakes, waterfalls; can even include marine environments.
Larvae are parasitic on leafhoppers and planthoppers, one species parasitizes crane flies.
One genus (Dolomedes) may be semi-aquatic, but most are terrestrial. The semi-aquatic genus only hunts on the water and does not live there.
Phylogenetic position in question; some consider this family to be a tribe.
The only genus in our dataset is "Psychoda," which is a drain fly species. They exist in very wet conditions, so I'm calling them aquatic.
Mostly wood-borers
In-between case; found "in moist habitats."
Larvae are mostly terrestrial, but some are aquatic. Enough uncertainty to classify these as both.
"Some larvae live in dung, others are leaf miners, stem-borers or feed in seed capsules, still others are aquatic predators and predators on other insect larvae in wet situations."
Larvae on fungi, decaying vegetation, plant roots, rotten wood, under bark, etc.
Bug Guide calls all larvae aquatic. Wikipedia says "most of the known larvae are semi-aquatic and some are aquatic." Since most are semi-aquatic or aquatic, classifying this family as aquatic.

common_name: Small dung flies, lesser dung flies

Notes: Usually parasites of athropods
Eggs sometimes laid underwater (semi-aquatic).
Order Thysanoptera: about half of species feed on fungi, some feed on green leaf tissues, some eat other arthropods.

common_name: Fungus moths, tineid moths, clothes moths
Notes: Larvae feed on fungi, lichens, detritus.
Larvae are parasites

This family is in the "Water mite" group (Hydrachnidia). Published literature about genera in this family is all about species that parasitize aquatic organisms, so this family is classified as aquatic.
